title: I am a cosigner on a car loan. The car got repossessed and I wasn't informed. What can I do?
question: Around 2008 I cosigned for a car loan for a friend. I lost touch with them and come 2010 I was surprised to find out there was a lien on my bank account. The bank informed me that it was from Ford re: the loan. I contacted my friend again and he said that the car was repossessed and he filed for bankruptcy thereafter so they shouldn't be coming after me.
answers:
You seem to have been the victim of what is commonly referred to as "sewer" service. The Plaintiff hires process servers who rather than actually serving the paper work on you dump it and then file something with the court saying they have served you.
The court then enters a judgment against you.
I know of one attorney in San Jose who is filing lawsuits against process servers for doing this contemptible service. Suggest you contact him.
Fred Schwinn, Esq. in San Jose, California.
I have added his link.
Good luck

You should have received many documents, such as the notice of intent to dispose of motor vehicle after they repossessed and before they sold it. Also, before a judgment can be entered against anyone, until delivery (through valid service) the summons and debt collection complaint.

Please see my legal guide, linked below, on your rights after repossession. Also, I have linked in the second link below my blog posting about setting aside a default judgment, as this one appears to have been obtained without valid service on you. My web site also has a ton of information on this issue. Please act promptly, as the courts have deadlines on setting aside invalid judgments and expect the defendant to hire a lawyer or do whatever is necessary soon after they learn of the court case and judgment. You should hire a debt collection defense attorney to help you with this.

Robert Stempler (please see DISCLAIMER below)
www.StopCollectionLawsuits.com

You should have received legal paperwork including a summons and complaint before a judgment was entered gainst you. If the first time you heard about this lawsuit was when your bank account was levied you might have the ability to set aside the judgment and defend yourself in the case. You might even be able to get the money that was taken out of your account returned to you.

You should contact an attorney to help you file the motion to set aside the judgment. In the meantime, you should go to the courthouse and get the court file. In it will be a document called a Proof of Service of Summons (POSS). The POSS will indicate how the creditor claims you were served and if it is false, that might help you in your motion. Act fast as the longer you wait the harder it is to set aside the judgment.

The consequences of co-signing a law can be enormous. Unfortunately, the only person you can blame (besides yourself) is your irresponsible friend. The creditor notified your friend that the account was delinquent (like he didn't know he wasn't paying), the creditor notified your friend that there was a reight to redeem the vehicle after it had been repoed, but he didn't bother to tell you any of that.

He just filed bankruptcy & left you to rot!

You may be able to go into court and ask that the judgment against you be set aside, but for the most part, notice on your friend may have contractually acted as notice to you. Fine Friend!

Hope this perspective helps!
